Chapter 1 - Fasteners

Overview:
A gas technician/fitter must fasten objects to various materials including wood, concrete, and steel. Understanding proper fastening techniques and selecting appropriate fasteners is essential for safe and secure installations.

Key Fastener Types:

**Screws:**
- Wood screws: Available in various types (Figure 1-1), lengths, and head styles (countersunk flat head, binding head)
- Self-tapping metal screws: Cut their own threads as they're driven in (Figure 1-2)
- Measured from underneath head to end (except countersunk heads measured end-to-end)

**Lag Bolts:**
- Heavy screws that fasten brackets to wooden members (Figure 1-4)
- Practical alternative to nut-and-bolt arrangement
- Larger sizes may require pilot holes
- Use with metal washers

**Bolts:**
- Available in various lengths, sizes, and configurations
- Thread types: National Fine (NF) or National Coarse (NC)
- Measured from underneath head to end
- Countersunk heads measured end-to-end
- Threaded rods (ready rods) can be cut to required length when manufactured bolts unavailable

**Anchoring Fasteners:**
- Insert anchors and rawl plugs: Lead and plastic shields used with machine bolts or lag screws (Figure 1-7a, 1-7b)
- Require correctly sized holes drilled into surface
- Drop-in anchors require special tool or pin to set
- Toggle bolts: Fix hangers to surfaces with hollow spaces behind them (Figure 1-7c)
  - Three types: spring wing (butterfly), tumble, riveted tumble
  - Bracing mechanism acts against back wall surface when tightened

**Hose Clamps:**
- Attach hose to pipe, pump, or other device
- Manual tightening type (Figure 1-8)
- Self-tightening (spring-loaded) type (Figure 1-9)
- Note: Generally not approved for natural gas or propane hoses

**Pipe Fasteners:**

Straps and Hangers:
- Pipe straps: Galvanized steel, copper, cast malleable iron, plastic; NPS 1/2 to NPS 4 (Figure 1-10a)
- Clevis hangers: Usually black steel; load nut must be securely tightened (Figure 1-10b)
- Adjustable steel ring hangers: Zinc-plated steel, NPS 3/4 to NPS 8 (Figure 1-10c)
- Adjustable swivel-ring hangers: Solid ring, NPS 3/4 to NPS 8 (Figure 1-10d)
- Pipe stays/valley hanger: Provides support from floor or wall (Figure 1-10e)

Hanger Rod and Attachments:
- Grappling bar (extension bar, hanger iron, strap iron): Various thicknesses, straight lengths or coils (Figure 1-11a)
- Threaded rod and rod coupling: Extends lengths where required (Figure 1-11b, c)
- Coachscrew/lag bolt and machine-threaded rod: One end screws into wood member (Figure 1-11c)

Beam Clamps and Brackets:
- Floor and ceiling flanges: Attach pipe hangers to ceiling or high building member (Figure 1-12a)
- Beam clamps: Used with hanger rods (Figure 1-12b)
- Riser clamps: Vertical pipe hangers that grip pipe forming solid support (Figure 1-12c)

**Electrical Fasteners:**
- Solderless connectors for mechanical and electrical connections without solder (Figure 1-13)
- Available in various sizes and shapes
- Insulating cap or boot covers conductors
- Some require common tools, others need special tools

**Sheet Metal Fasteners:**
- Self-taping and self-locking screws most common
- S-cleats and drive cleats connect ductwork sections (Figure 1-14)
- Aluminum tape: Attaches insulation to ductwork, various widths, some with fiber threads for strength

Chapter 2 - Hand tools

[Content includes threading tools, reamers, taps, dies, and related equipment]

**Reamers:**

Straight, fluted, ratchet reamer (Figure 2-36):
- For hand or power reaming
- Capacity up to NPS 2

Spiral ratchet reamer (Figure 2-37):
- Hand use only - UNSAFE with power vice
- Capacity up to NPS 4
- Can bind in pipe causing injury if used with power vice

**Threads:**

Straight threads:
- Parallel - peaks have same diameter
- Used on bolts
- Used where leakproof connection not needed

Tapered threads (Figure 2-38):
- Mesh together when tightened to produce leakproof joint
- Standard piping threads: 3/4 in taper per ft
- Right-hand threaded (clockwise) unless noted as left-hand
- Thread size increases with pipe size

Thread engagement:
- 7-8 threads engaged for most sizes
- More threads for pipe >NPS 1-1/4

NPS pipe size and threads per inch (Table 2-1):
- 1/8: 27 threads/inch
- 1/4, 3/8: 18 threads/inch
- 1/2, 3/4: 14 threads/inch
- 1 to 2: 11.5 threads/inch
- 2-1/2 to 12: 8 threads/inch

**Thread Cutting Oil:**
- Ensures smooth finish and accurate work
- Functions:
  - Reduces friction
  - Cools tool and pipe
  - Flushes away metal chips

Ingredients:
- Fatty oil: Provides even film
- Sulphur/chlorine: Tough chemical film between cutting edges and material
- Antifoam agent: Reduces surface tension and foam
- Germicide: Lessens infection risk if operator injured

Important notes:
- Clean or poor-grade oil results in poor thread quality
- Check level and quality regularly
- Not a lubricant for tools

**Pipe Taps:**
- Cut or repair internal pipe threads (tapping)
- Sizes: NPS 1/8 to NPS 2
- Diameter and pitch stamped on shank
- Flutes catch metal chips
- Square end for tap wrench grip
- Taper hole with taper pipe reamer before tapping

**Pipe Dies:**

Full-width dies (Figure 2-40):
- Width equals length of thread to be cut
- Die moves along pipe as it cuts
- Flush with pipe end when complete
- Used for smaller pipe sizes (less effort)

Receding dies (Figure 2-41):
- Width less than thread length
- Must travel along pipe and recede from centerline
- Used for larger pipe sizes (considerable surface area)

**Hand Threaders:**

Ratchet, drop-head threaders (Figure 2-42):
- Quick and easy for small jobs or close quarters
- Interchangeable dies
- Can reverse dies for close-to-wall threading
- Two types:
  - Exposed-ratchet: NPS 1/8 to NPS 1
  - Enclosed-ratchet: NPS 1/8 to NPS 2

Jam-proof ratchet threader (Figure 2-43):
- Uses receding dies
- One die set threads NPS 1 to NPS 2
- Jam-proof action automatically disengages when complete

Quick-opening threader (Figure 2-44):
- Designed for power equipment
- Lever releases dies after thread cut
- Two styles:
  - Mono-die head: One pipe size
  - Universal-die head: Adjustable for multiple sizes

**Thumb Drills:**
- Used to drill out orifices (Figure 2-45)

Chapter 3 - Power tools and safety

[Content includes power tools, powder-actuated tools, and power threading equipment]

**Portable Grinders:**

Safety rules:
- Never use in a slot
- Ensure machine can't be wrenched from hands when working corners/edges
- Electric grinders: Check power cord condition, work in dry location
- Pneumatic grinders: Adjust pressure to recommended level, ensure adequate oil supply, check air hose condition

**Powder-Actuated Tools:**

Definition: Use explosive charge force to drive fasteners into hard materials (concrete, steel)

Safety:
- Tools differ by manufacturer - familiarize with each separately
- Study manufacturer's specifications for type, size, charge
- Know misfire procedures
- Fastener velocity measured at 2m (6ft) from muzzle

Types:

Low-velocity (Hilti type) - Figure 3-17:
- Captive piston principle
- Pin and piston move <100 m/s (<325 ft/s)
- Built-in device prevents firing if >7° off work surface
- Must be close to vertical

Medium-velocity (Ramset type):
- Pin travels 325-500 ft/s (100-150 m/s)

High-velocity (Omark, Remington, Phillips) - Figure 3-18:
- Limited applications
- No piston
- Pin discharged >500 ft/s (>150 m/s), often up to 1500 ft/s (450 m/s)

**Propulsion Methods:**

Impact propulsion:
- Gap between fastener and piston
- Stop ring absorbs impact
- Replace stop ring when deformed
- Hilti tools use this method

Contact propulsion:
- Work surface, fastener, and piston in direct contact

Co-acting propulsion:
- Only piston and fastener in contact
- Away from work surface

**Cartridge Types:**

Color coding (Figure 3-19):
- Weakest: Grey
- Strongest: Purple
- Start with weakest, increase one step at a time

Cartridge identification:
- Low-velocity: Brass cases
- High-velocity: Nickel cases
- Types: Crimped or wadded (Figure 3-20)
- Crimped (HILTI): Painted tip shows strength, keeps cartridge dry
- Wadded: Not used in low-velocity/captive piston tools (can plug vent ports)

**Fasteners:**

Three basic types (Figure 3-21):
- Headed
- Threaded
- Eyelet

How they work:
- Point forces material aside
- Fastener penetrates and "seats" without excessive deformation
- Compressive force squeezes shank for holding strength
- Some have altered threads for increased strength
- Some have guides for greater holding or prevent over-penetration

**Power Threaders:**

"Hand-held" power-driven threading machines (Figure 3-22):
- Electric powered
- Thread 1/8 to 2 in pipe/rod
- Lightweight compared to full-sized machines
- Use with approved vice and support arm

Powered threading machines (Figure 3-23):
- Medium to large jobs
- Any required size for gas piping
- Die options: ratchet, mono, quick-opening, self-opening, semi-automatic
- High torque - requires training
- Safety critical

Common Dos and Don'ts:
Do:
- Keep shirts, sleeves, jackets buttoned
- Keep area clear and free of slippery materials
- Keep handles dry and clean
- Ensure adequate power supply
- Support long pipe lengths with additional stands

Don't:
- Wear gloves or loose clothing
- Use dull or damaged dies
- Use if machine damaged
- Use wrong length extension cords
- Use stationary machines without working dead-man switch

**Die Heads (Figure 3-24):**
- Mono die head: One pipe size
- Self-opening die head
- Bolt die head
- Semi-automatic die head
- Quick opening die head

Scenario 1: You need to install a gas pipe hanger system for a horizontal natural gas line running along a concrete ceiling in a basement. The pipe is 2-inch steel and will be approximately 15 feet long between supports. You have access to various fasteners including toggle bolts, insert anchors, lag bolts, and different types of hangers.
11. Describe your fastener selection process for this installation. Include: (a) what type of anchoring system you would use for the concrete ceiling, (b) what type of hanger would be most appropriate, and (c) what factors you need to consider for proper spacing and support.
Scenario 2: During a service call, you discover that a flexible gas connector hose has become loose at its connection point to a gas appliance. You notice that the original hose clamp appears to be a basic gear-type clamp that may not be providing adequate securing force. The hose carries natural gas and the connection must be both secure and safe.
12. Explain the steps you would take to properly secure this connection. Include: (a) safety precautions you must take before working on the connection, (b) what type of fastening system would be most appropriate for this gas application, (c) any restrictions or considerations specific to natural gas hose connections mentioned in the chapter.

PART A: MULTIPLE CHOICE

c) Flat head machine screw

PART B: SHORT ANSWER

Four factors to consider when fastening piping or equipment: a) Type of material to which you must fasten the piping or equipment b) Type of equipment that you are fastening c) Weight and shape of the equipment d) Whether the equipment has support from above or below (Also acceptable: whether expansion or vibration is a factor; the number of fasteners or supports required)
10. National Fine vs National Coarse threads: National Fine (NF) threads have more threads per inch and provide finer adjustment and stronger holding power in thinner materials. National Coarse (NC) threads have fewer threads per inch and are easier to assemble/disassemble. Threaded rod is used when the correct bolt length is not available and adjustments are limited - you can cut threaded rod to the required length for custom applications.
PART C: CASE STUDIES
11. Gas pipe hanger installation on concrete ceiling: (a) Anchoring system: Use insert anchors (rawl plugs) for the concrete ceiling, as they require drilling correctly sized holes and provide secure attachment to masonry materials. (b) Hanger type: Use adjustable steel ring hangers or clevis hangers, as they can accommodate the 2-inch pipe size and provide proper support. Clevis hangers are typically black steel and suitable for gas piping. (c) Factors to consider: Proper spacing based on pipe size and weight (typically every 6-10 feet for 2-inch steel pipe), ensure adequate load-bearing capacity for the total weight, consider thermal expansion of the pipe, select correct size fasteners for the expected load, and ensure the hangers allow for any potential vibration.
12. Loose gas hose connection repair: (a) Safety precautions: Turn off gas supply at the appliance shutoff valve and at the meter if necessary, ensure adequate ventilation, check for gas leaks using approved leak detection solution (never use open flame), and follow lockout/tagout procedures. (b) Appropriate fastening system: Replace with a proper gear-type hose clamp designed for gas applications, ensuring it provides adequate clamping force. The clamp should be sized correctly for the hose diameter and connection. (c) Gas-specific considerations: The chapter notes that hose clamps are generally not approved for use with hoses that carry either natural gas or propane, so this connection may require a different approved connector or replacement of the entire flexible connector with an approved gas connector system. Always verify local codes and manufacturer specifications for gas appliance connections.

11. Voltage Measurement Procedure: Safety precautions: Ensure power is on to the circuit, verify proper meter operation, check test leads for damage, and be aware of live electrical connections.
